title: Afterpay's David Hancock five sleeps from $136m
text:
Time must have ground to a ponderous crawl for Afterpay Touch executive director David Hancock. Announcing its founders’ $103.5 million “secondary sell-down” on June 11, the buy now, pay later sensation noted that "[Anthony] Eisen, [Nick] Molnar and Mr Hancock have each confirmed that they will not sell any further shares until at least 120 days from today”. On July 2, the company added that "Anthony and Nick do not intend to sell any further shares during the current financial year," but glaringly, didn't mention "David".

So five more sleeps! Come Tuesday, Hancock can expect an unscheduled house call from his stockbroker. Before dawn.

He is, after all, sitting on 950,000 ordinary Afterpay shares (in his wife Fiona’s name) plus 2.7 million options with a dead-set gorgeous strike price of $2.70 and another 200,000 options exercisable at $1. A tranche of 1.5 million options vested last month, triggering a $20 million FY20 income tax liability payable by April next year. Tolerable enough, given all-up his shareholding would fetch $136.1 million at Wednesday’s closing price. No child of his should ever have to work.

But the Hancock fortune isn’t banked just yet. And when his voluntary escrow ends next week, can he even trade in Afterpay while remaining a director of the company (he’s set to retire from the board at next month’s AGM)? Not if he’s in possession of material information.

Last week, Afterpay provided to AUSTRAC the interim report of the external auditor AUSTRAC ordered it to appoint back on June 12, having had “reasonable grounds to suspect that Afterpay is a reporting entity that has contravened and/or is contravening section 32 and 81 of the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Act 2006”.
description: Can the Hancock fortune be banked before AUSTRAC ruins the party?
